newsitem.title: USA: Ohio Gov approves $432.5 mln bonds for highways.
newsitem.headline: Ohio Gov approves $432.5 mln bonds for highways.

text.p: Ohio Gov. George Voinovich late Monday signed into law a bill authorizing the state Department of Transportation to sell up to $432.5 million of highway bonds over the next two years, a department spokesman said Tuesday.

The bonds backed by the state's gasoline tax will fund general construction projects throughout Ohio in the fiscal 1998-99 bienium, which begins on July 1, department communications director Pieter Wykoff said.
The Ohio transportation department spends $800 million to $900 million each year on construction projects, funding some improvements through cash and others through bond sales, Wykoff added.
No date has been set for a bond sale, which will be coordinated by the department's finance director based on cash flow and federal transportation funding, Wykoff said.

The legislation also included $90 million of bonding authority for the state infrustructure bank created last year to provide loans to local governments for funding transportation improvements, Wykoff noted.
The legislation authorizes up to $50 million of bonds for fiscal 1998 and $40 million for fiscal 1999, Wykoff said. Those bonds will be issued by the state treasurer's office, he added.

Ohio's revolving loan program offers low-interest loans to fund such improvements as interchanges, airport expansions and highway projects. It was one of 10 states included in a pilot program created by Congress in the National Highway System Act of 1995.
